p.s: In contemplation of Shakespeare's language, it's sure to say that it reinforces conveying his message, which is to explain the changement of beauty throughout the time and the maintaining feeling of love.
This his precise use of language filled with rhetorical devices empowers illustrating the specific imagery of this sonnet.
Firstly, the poet provides a certain argumentation that is supported by the structure of quatrains in a couplet.
Each one does convey a significant message.
In the first quatrain, the playwright mentions the aspect of mortality (cf. l. 2).
He indicates that everyone Hass to face death and beauty does not have an influence on that (cf. l. 3).
In order to convey this message, the poet makes use of an enumeration: Since breass, not stone, nor earth, nor boundless sea (l. 1).

He does also intend to contrast that nature (the stone, the earth, brass and the boundless sea) does not have the altering process of youthful beauty under control, it's rather the sad mortality (l. 2), which highlights that our mortality has much more power than nature: the fact that we will experience death can't be changed by any circumstances.
In addition, he compares the power of beauty with the aspect of mortality.
Another personification and rhetorical question in line three and four: How with this rage show beauty hold a plea, whose action is no stronger than a flower?.
This simile remarks that beauty is not as strong as a flower and that it has no power to resist against the fact that it alters throughout the time.

In the second quatrain, the writer extends his themes into imagery by including strong symbols, such as summer's honey breath (l. 5), wrackful siege of batt'ring days (l. 6) where he draws a strong contrast and at the same time uses parallelism to compare a rataer positive imagery of sommer'ssummer's honey breath with the siege of battering days which contributes to conflicts that we expierence in our lifetime, that influence our beauty.
In the nex two lines, the poet makes use of a metaphor when rocks impregnant are not so stout, nor gates of steel so strong, but time decays?.

He indicates with these personifications, that time does not pous by and the power of rocks and gates are nothing compared to the impact the wrackful siegt of battring days (l. 6) has on an individual.
Additionally, in the third quatrain Shakespeare uses another personification: shall time's best jewel from time's chest lie hid? (l. 10).
The jewel, a reference to youth, which is the best time in our life, where beauty is the most significant and its spoil of beauty (l. 12) cannot be forbidden.
Thus, he comploys rrepitition in order to underline the importance of beauty, as well as time (cf. l. 3, l. 8, l. 10, l. 12).

In the couplet, the intention and motivation of Shakespeare becomes clear: His love to the addressee is so powerful that not even a blank inle on a letter can't stop the shine of his love (cf. l. 14).
He conveys the message, that even though circumstances that have a huge impact on the life of an individual, from beauty to time, nothing comes against his love to the addressee.
Furthermore, strong negative adjectives like wrackful (l. 6) or sad (l. 2) evokes the impression of a tensed, melo-dramatic and serious atmosphere.
In the context of Shakespeare, catalogue of sonnets, it's certain to say that it contributes to certain aspects that are also given in the other sonnets.
Sonnet 65 does also address themes like love, beauty, death and youth.

When it comes to imagery, it's sure to say that he does also draw visualisations of nature, for instance flower, rocks or summer's honey breath (cf. l. 4ff.), just as he did in his former sonnets, like in 130.
Compared to other sonnets it's significant, that in this sonnet he doesn't address a muse in form of a femininfeminine peron, he rather addresses youth.

Taking everything into account, I come to the conclusion that Shakespeare's Sonnet 65 is another argumentation of the altering processproccess of youth and beauty and comapres it his love towards his addressee, which is more powerful at the same time eternal and unchangeable.
